This token gives you a preview of the story.

Project Bookworm is releasing one section per epoch from
Blade of Baz, by Jillian Plomin.
Collect the whole book to receive a signed special

Token 26 Preview:
Erica tightened the strap on her bracer and laced it
through the buckle, then picked up her back scabbard
and awkwardly wriggled into it.
She glanced out the window.
I wonder if I can sneak out for a glimpse of the sunrise.
Resolving to try, she pulled out the heaviest cloak in her
closet, tossed it over her shoulders, slid her arms through
the holes, and fastened the front. She grabbed her mittens
and gingerly opened her notoriously creaky bedroom door a
crack. She squeezed through and carefully closed it again,
then tiptoed down the back stair case and through the
meandering corridors to the kitchens. Hunching down, Erica
pushed hard against the tiny back door that led outside
behind the castle. As she gently closed the door, a low
voice broke the morning's silence.

Token 26 Preview:
Lidian shrugged her shoulders in an attempt to shift the
quiver on her back. She’d filled it with so many arrows,
the weight of it threatened to pull her backward to the
ground. Another jammed-full quiver dangled from her hip as
she adjusted her legs on the tree limb she’d planted
herself on. An oblong satchel nestled in the crook of a
couple of branches contained still more arrows. Lidian was
prepared for a busy night. She was counting on it.
Several yards away, she knew, Nasira sat in another tree,
equally arrow-laden, waiting. And beyond that, a third,
fourth, and fifth archer peered into the night from the
edge of the forest tree line, arrows notched and bows at
the ready. Lidian had trained them herself, although these
particular recruits had been practicing for years before
they joined the rebel effort. Tonight, they did what all
archers do at the onset of a battle. Breathe steadily,
slow the heartbeat, keep eyes on the target, unflinching.
Archers were not like soldiers with swords, who thrive on
hyperbolic speeches from their commanders, hearts pumping,
arms flailing, hoping to leave a trail of struck down
enemies in their chaotic wake. No, bowmanship required a
quiet spirit. It required exacting accuracy. The best
archers are immune to distraction.
In the moonless dark all five archers watched five
pinpricks of light in the distance. They were the torches
lighting the five manned sentry posts of the Citadel. The
battlements on the far side of the Citadel, the interior
side facing the town, were left unmanned this night.
Lidian trained her eyes on the light farthest from the
forest. Her assigned target. She slowly inhaled. It had
to be midnight by now. She exhaled. Movement made her
heart jump. She tamped it down, willing herself to remain
calm. A second light appeared. The relieving guard. The
first light lifted up, then down. The retiring guard.
Lidian took a breath and took aim. She pulled back the
string. Air hissed through her lips as she released, and
the arrow soared, seemingly into the distant stars. She
did not stop to see if she hit her target. In an instant,
another arrow was notched, released, and sailing before
the first struck solid form. This was followed by a third
and fourth.
Two breaths were all it took. Two breaths and four arrows,
then the dots of light vanished, their glow emanating
upward from the floor of the alure. Lidian considered for
only an instant whether the third and fourth shots were a
waste of arrows, but hastily threw the thought away. It was
better to be sure the guards fell quickly. She grabbed her
satchel from the tree crook, maneuvered her way down limb
to limb, lighted quickly to the ground, and ran.

Blade of Baz Preview 26.name: Blade of Baz
Blade of Baz Preview 26.author: Jillian Plomin
Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?
